title: David Coulthard relishes 'exciting new era for Formula One' as former driver is confirmed for Channel 4 presenting role
title_page: David Coulthard relishes 'exciting new era for Formula One' as former driver is confirmed for Channel 4 presenting role | Daily Mail Online
text:
David Coulthard will be part of the presentation team for Channel Four's Formula One coverage that starts in March.
Coulthard, who has been one of the main BBC pundits throughout their coverage which C4 are taking over, is co-founder of Whisper Films who have won the tender process to produce C4's output.
The other founders of Whisper Films are Sunil Patel, a former F1 BBC producer and BT football presenter Jake Humphrey.
David Coulthard, pictured with Sir Jackie Stewart in Singapore last year, will cover Formula One for Channel 4
Coutlhard insists it is 'exciting times' for Whisper Films - the production company he is a co-founder of

However, Humphrey will not be part of C4's on screen team.
'This is an exciting time for the sport and an exciting time for Whisper Films,' Coulthard said.
'The F1 world has been incredibly impressed with what Whisper has delivered over the last five years and Channel 4's decision is testament to that.
'I'm looking forward to being part of an exciting new era for Formula One, with Whisper Films and our proven level of creativity and innovation very much at the heart of that.'
It's not the greatest surprise that Whisper Films won the tender against North One as they are 20 per cent owned by C4 since last August.
Coulthard, seen here celebrating after winning in Monaco back in 2002, retired from driving in 2008
The Scottish driver won 13 times and finished his career with Red Bull
Coulthard worked as a consultant for Red Bull after quitting the cockpit before joining the BBC as a pundit
Ed Havard, Channel 4's head of TV events and sport added: 'Whisper Films outlined an extremely impressive and exciting vision for their F1 coverage, with outstanding on and off screen talent as an integral part of their pitch.
'We are delighted that David Coulthard will be at the heart of Channel 4's coverage and look forward to announcing the full presenting team in the coming weeks.'
The 44-year-old Coulthard first drove for Williams F1 in the 1994 season, succeeding the late Ayrton Senna. He spent two years there before moving to McLaren.
He finished second in the driver's championship in 2001 to Michael Schumacher. The final move of his career would see him head to Red Bull in 2005, securing their first podium a year later.
After retiring from Formula One in 2008, Coulthard continued to work as a consultant for Red Bull before joining up with the BBC as a commentator and pundit for their racing coverage.
The BBC regained the exclusive broadcasting rights to Formula One in 2009 before agreeing a seven-year deal to share them with Sky Sports in 2012. But after announcing a Â£35million cut to its sport budget the corporation pulled out of its contract with three years still to run.
